expanded_description: This section provides a comprehensive set of review questions covering all topics from Chapter 10: Introduction to Static Electricity, Electrostatic Induction, Coulomb's Law, Coulomb's Law (Three Charges), Ohm's Law, Electric Power, Series Circuits, and Parallel Circuits. Students will apply their knowledge to reinforce understanding and prepare for the chapter test.

core_concept.principle: Review and practice are essential for mastering electricity concepts. These questions integrate knowledge from all chapter sections to build connections between topics and strengthen understanding of how electric charges behave, how circuits work, and how to analyze both electrostatic and current electricity systems.
core_concept.explanation: Think of learning electricity like building a complete electrical system—each section adds a new component: static charges, forces between charges, the fundamental relationships of voltage, current, and resistance, power calculations, and circuit configurations. Review questions help you see how all these pieces fit together, from understanding why a balloon sticks to a wall to calculating the exact current in every branch of a complex parallel circuit.

sections.introduction: Questions reviewing the fundamental concepts of static electricity—charge, attraction and repulsion, conductors and insulators, and charging by friction.

worked_examples.title: Question 1.1: Charge Types
worked_examples.problem: A plastic rod is rubbed with a wool cloth and becomes negatively charged. a) What happened to the electrons? b) What is the charge on the wool? c) If the rod is brought near small pieces of paper, what happens and why?

step_by_step.explanation: Electrons transferred from the wool to the rod. The rod gained electrons.
The wool lost electrons, so it becomes positively charged.
The rod attracts the paper. The paper is neutral, but the rod's charge polarizes the paper molecules, creating a slight opposite charge on the near side, causing attraction.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Rod gained electrons; b) Wool is positive; c) Rod attracts paper through polarization.

worked_examples.title: Question 1.2: Conductors vs Insulators
worked_examples.problem: Explain why a metal rod held in your hand cannot be charged by rubbing, but a plastic rod can. How could you charge a metal rod by rubbing?

step_by_step.explanation: Metal is a conductor. Any charge that builds up flows through your body to ground, so it cannot accumulate.
Plastic is an insulator. Charge stays where it's placed and cannot flow away.
Hold the metal rod with an insulating handle so charge cannot escape to ground, then rub it.

worked_examples.final_answer: Conductors allow charge to flow to ground; insulators trap charge. Use an insulating handle to charge a conductor.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Conductor vs insulator in static charging.

worked_examples.title: Question 1.3: Attraction and Repulsion
worked_examples.problem: Two balloons are both rubbed on hair and become negatively charged. What happens when they are brought near each other? What if one balloon is rubbed on hair and the other on silk?

step_by_step.explanation: Both become negative. Like charges repel, so balloons push apart.
Balloon on hair becomes negative; balloon on silk might become positive depending on materials. If opposite, they attract.

worked_examples.final_answer: Two negative balloons repel; opposite charges attract.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Like charges repel, unlike charges attract.

sections.introduction: Questions reviewing induction, polarization, and charging by induction.

worked_examples.title: Question 2.1: Induction vs Contact
worked_examples.problem: A negatively charged rod is brought near a neutral metal sphere without touching. Describe the charge distribution on the sphere. What is the net charge of the sphere?

step_by_step.explanation: Electrons in the sphere are repelled by the negative rod, so they move to the far side.
Near side becomes positive (electron deficiency), far side becomes negative (electron excess).
The sphere is still neutral overall—charge is just separated.

worked_examples.final_answer: Near side positive, far side negative, net charge zero.

worked_examples.title: Question 2.2: Charging by Induction
worked_examples.problem: Describe the steps to give a neutral metal sphere a negative charge using a positively charged rod, without touching the rod to the sphere.

step_by_step.explanation: Bring the positive rod near the sphere (not touching). Electrons are attracted to the near side, leaving far side positive.
Ground the sphere (touch far side) while rod is nearby. Electrons flow from ground to the sphere (attracted by the positive rod).
Remove the positive rod. Sphere now has excess electrons—negatively charged.

worked_examples.final_answer: Induce separation, ground, remove ground, then remove rod. Sphere becomes negative (opposite to rod).

worked_examples.title: Question 2.3: Polarization
worked_examples.problem: Explain why a charged balloon sticks to a neutral wall, even though the wall is an insulator.

step_by_step.explanation: Balloon is negatively charged from rubbing.
The wall's molecules polarize—electron clouds shift slightly away from the balloon, leaving the near side of each molecule slightly positive.
Attraction between balloon's negative charge and induced positive charge on wall surface causes sticking.

worked_examples.final_answer: The balloon polarizes the wall molecules, inducing opposite charge on the near surface, causing attraction.

sections.introduction: Questions applying Coulomb's Law to calculate forces between two point charges.

worked_examples.title: Question 3.1: Basic Coulomb's Law
worked_examples.problem: Two point charges, $q_1 = +6\ \mu\text{C}$ and $q_2 = -4\ \mu\text{C}$, are separated by $0.3\ \text{m}$. Calculate the magnitude of the electric force between them. Is it attractive or repulsive?

step_by_step.explanation: Charges are opposite (positive and negative), so force is attractive.

worked_examples.title: Question 3.2: Distance Effect
worked_examples.problem: Two charges attract with a force of $0.6\ \text{N}$ when separated by $0.1\ \text{m}$. What will be the force when the distance is increased to $0.3\ \text{m}$?

worked_examples.title: Question 3.3: Charge Effect
worked_examples.problem: Two identical charges repel with force $F$. If one charge is doubled and the other is tripled, what is the new force in terms of $F$?

step_by_step.explanation: Let original charges be $q$ each. Product $= q^2 \propto F$

sections.introduction: Questions applying superposition principle to systems with three charges.

worked_examples.title: Question 4.1: Three Charges in a Line
worked_examples.problem: Three charges are arranged on the x-axis: $q_1 = +3\ \mu\text{C}$ at $x = 0$, $q_2 = -2\ \mu\text{C}$ at $x = 0.2\ \text{m}$, $q_3 = +5\ \mu\text{C}$ at $x = 0.5\ \text{m}$. Find the net force on $q_2$.

step_by_step.explanation: $q_1$ positive, $q_2$ negative → attract. $q_1$ left of $q_2$, so force left. $r_{12} = 0.2\ \text{m}$. $F_{12} = k|q_1q_2|/r_{12}^2 = (9\times10^9) \times (3\times10^{-6})(2\times10^{-6}) / (0.2)^2 = (9\times10^9) \times (6\times10^{-12}) / 0.04 = (9\times10^9) \times (1.5\times10^{-10}) = 1.35\ \text{N}$ left $= -1.35\ \text{N}$

$q_2$ negative, $q_3$ positive → attract. $q_3$ right of $q_2$, so force right. $r_{23} = 0.3\ \text{m}$. $F_{32} = k|q_2q_3|/r_{23}^2 = (9\times10^9) \times (2\times10^{-6})(5\times10^{-6}) / (0.3)^2 = (9\times10^9) \times (10\times10^{-12}) / 0.09 = (9\times10^9) \times (1.11\times10^{-10}) = 1.0\ \text{N}$ right $= +1.0\ \text{N}$

worked_examples.final_answer: Net force $= 0.35$ N directed to the left.

worked_examples.title: Question 4.2: Equilibrium Position
worked_examples.problem: A charge $q = +2\ \mu\text{C}$ is placed between two fixed charges: $q_1 = +8\ \mu\text{C}$ at $x = 0$ and $q_2 = +2\ \mu\text{C}$ at $x = 0.3\ \text{m}$. Where should $q$ be placed so that the net force on it is zero?

step_by_step.explanation: Let $x$ be distance from $q_1$. Force from $q_1$: $F_1 = k q q_1/x^2$ (repulsion, right if $q$ is right of $q_1$). Force from $q_2$: $F_2 = k q q_2/(0.3-x)^2$ (repulsion, left). For equilibrium: $F_1 = F_2$

worked_examples.final_answer: The charge should be placed at $x = 0.2$ m (20 cm from the left charge).

sections.introduction: Questions applying Ohm's Law and understanding voltage, current, and resistance relationships.

worked_examples.title: Question 5.1: Basic Ohm's Law
worked_examples.problem: A $15\ \text{V}$ battery is connected across a $5\ \Omega$ resistor. How much current flows?

worked_examples.title: Question 5.2: Finding Resistance
worked_examples.problem: A current of $0.25\ \text{A}$ flows when a $9\ \text{V}$ battery is connected. What is the resistance?
worked_examples.concept_applied: Finding resistance from voltage and current.

worked_examples.title: Question 5.3: Finding Voltage
worked_examples.problem: A $12\ \Omega$ resistor carries a current of $1.5\ \text{A}$. What is the voltage across it?
worked_examples.concept_applied: Finding voltage from current and resistance.

worked_examples.title: Question 5.4: Current Change
worked_examples.problem: A resistor draws $0.8\ \text{A}$ from a $12\ \text{V}$ source. What current will it draw from a $9\ \text{V}$ source?

sections.introduction: Questions applying power equations and energy calculations.

worked_examples.title: Question 6.1: Power from Voltage and Current
worked_examples.problem: A device operates at $120\ \text{V}$ and draws $1.2\ \text{A}$. What is its power consumption?

worked_examples.title: Question 6.2: Power from Resistance
worked_examples.problem: A $10\ \Omega$ resistor carries a current of $2\ \text{A}$. How much power does it dissipate?

worked_examples.title: Question 6.3: Finding Current from Power
worked_examples.problem: A $1500\ \text{W}$ hair dryer runs on $120\ \text{V}$. What current does it draw?
worked_examples.concept_applied: Finding current from power and voltage.

worked_examples.title: Question 6.4: Energy Consumption
worked_examples.problem: A $60\ \text{W}$ fan runs for 8 hours. How much energy does it use in kWh? At $0.15 per kWh, what does it cost?

sections.introduction: Questions analyzing series circuits—equivalent resistance, current, voltage drops, and power.

worked_examples.title: Question 7.1: Equivalent Resistance
worked_examples.problem: Three resistors, $R_1 = 10\ \Omega$, $R_2 = 20\ \Omega$, and $R_3 = 30\ \Omega$, are connected in series. Find the equivalent resistance.

worked_examples.title: Question 7.2: Current in Series
worked_examples.problem: A $24\ \text{V}$ battery is connected to the series combination in Question 7.1. Find the current in the circuit.

worked_examples.title: Question 7.3: Voltage Drops
worked_examples.problem: For the circuit in Question 7.2, find the voltage drop across each resistor.

worked_examples.title: Question 7.4: Power in Series
worked_examples.problem: For the circuit in Question 7.2, find the power dissipated by each resistor and the total power.

sections.introduction: Questions analyzing parallel circuits—equivalent resistance, branch currents, voltage, and power.

worked_examples.title: Question 8.1: Equivalent Resistance
worked_examples.problem: Three resistors, $R_1 = 20\ \Omega$, $R_2 = 30\ \Omega$, and $R_3 = 60\ \Omega$, are connected in parallel. Find the equivalent resistance.

worked_examples.title: Question 8.2: Branch Currents
worked_examples.problem: A $30\ \text{V}$ battery is connected to the parallel combination in Question 8.1. Find the current in each branch and the total current.

worked_examples.title: Question 8.3: Power in Parallel
worked_examples.problem: For the circuit in Question 8.2, find the power dissipated by each resistor and the total power.

worked_examples.title: Question 8.4: Current Divider
worked_examples.problem: Two resistors, $R_1 = 10\ \Omega$ and $R_2 = 40\ \Omega$, are connected in parallel. The total current entering the parallel combination is $2.5\ \text{A}$. Find the current through each resistor using the current divider formula.

sections.introduction: Questions that combine multiple concepts from different chapter sections.

worked_examples.title: Question 9.1: Coulomb's Law and Circuits
worked_examples.problem: How does the force between two charges change if they are placed in a medium like water instead of air? How does this relate to resistance in circuits?

step_by_step.explanation: In a medium, the force is reduced by a factor called the dielectric constant $\kappa$: $F = \frac{k|q_1q_2|}{\kappa r^2}$. Water has a high dielectric constant ($\kappa \approx 80$), so force is much weaker.
This is analogous to resistance—different materials have different resistivities that affect current flow. Both involve how the medium affects electric phenomena.

worked_examples.final_answer: Force is reduced by the dielectric constant; this is analogous to how resistivity affects current in circuits.

worked_examples.title: Question 9.2: Series-Parallel Comparison
worked_examples.problem: Two identical light bulbs are available. Compare their brightness when connected in series versus parallel across the same battery. Explain why one configuration produces more light.

step_by_step.explanation: In series, total resistance is $2R$, current is $V/(2R)$, power per bulb $= I^2R = (V/(2R))^2 R = V^2/(4R)$. Each bulb gets $1/4$ the power it would get alone.
In parallel, each bulb gets full voltage $V$, so power per bulb $= V^2/R$ (full brightness).
Parallel gives 4 times more power per bulb than series, so bulbs are much brighter in parallel.

worked_examples.final_answer: Parallel gives full brightness ($V^2/R$ per bulb); series gives only $V^2/(4R)$ per bulb. Parallel is brighter.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Comparing series and parallel power distribution.

worked_examples.title: Question 9.3: Induction and Conductors
worked_examples.problem: Explain why a charged object can attract a neutral conductor through induction, but the conductor remains neutral overall. How does this relate to grounding in circuits?

step_by_step.explanation: The charged object causes charge separation in the conductor—opposite charge moves to the near side, like charge to the far side. The conductor remains neutral overall.
The near side opposite charge causes attraction, even though net charge is zero.
Grounding in circuits provides a path for charge to flow, similar to how grounding during induction allows charge to transfer, leaving the object permanently charged.

worked_examples.final_answer: Induction separates charges without changing net charge; grounding allows permanent charge transfer, analogous to circuit grounding.

worked_examples.title: Question 9.4: Power and Energy
worked_examples.problem: A $100\ \text{W}$ incandescent bulb and a $15\ \text{W}$ LED bulb produce the same amount of light. If each is used for 5 hours per day, how much energy does each use in a month (30 days)? At $0.18 per kWh, what is the monthly cost difference?
worked_examples.final_answer: Incandescent: $15$ kWh, $2.70; LED: $2.25$ kWh, $0.41; savings $2.29 per month.

worked_examples.title: Question 9.5: Ohm's Law and Power
worked_examples.problem: A heater is designed to operate at $240\ \text{V}$ and draws $10\ \text{A}$. a) What is its power? b) What is its resistance? c) If the voltage drops to $220\ \text{V}$, what power does it actually deliver? (Assume resistance constant)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Combining Ohm's Law and power equations.

summary: This review section provides comprehensive practice questions covering all topics from Chapter 10: Introduction to Static Electricity (charge types, conductors/insulators, charging by friction), Electrostatic Induction (charge separation, polarization, charging by induction), Coulomb's Law ($F = k|q_1q_2|/r^2$ for two charges), Coulomb's Law for Three Charges (superposition principle, vector addition, equilibrium problems), Ohm's Law ($V = IR$ with applications), Electric Power ($P = VI$, $P = I^2R$, $P = V^2/R$, energy and cost calculations), Series Circuits (constant current, $R_{eq} = R_1 + R_2 + ...$, voltage division, power distribution), and Parallel Circuits (constant voltage, $1/R_{eq} = 1/R_1 + 1/R_2 + ...$, current division, power distribution). Questions range from basic definitions and conceptual explanations to mathematical calculations and real-world applications. Mixed review questions connect concepts across sections, helping students synthesize their understanding of how static electricity relates to current electricity, how series and parallel circuits differ in power distribution, and how energy consumption translates to cost. Working through these questions reinforces learning, identifies areas needing further study, and prepares students for the chapter test. Success with these questions demonstrates mastery of electricity concepts at the Grade 9-10 level.
